sub:
Kelvin, Fahrenheit, Celsius
Named for Lord William Thomson Kelvin, an English physicist. The kelvin, unit of thermodynamic temperature, is the fraction 1/273.16 of the thermodynamic temperature of the triple point of water (13th CGPM, Conférence Générale des Poids et Mesures, 1967).;Body Temp. (Normal);309.65;Body Temp. (High);311.15;Boiling temp. of water;373.15;Freezing Temp. of water;273.15;Room temp.;298.15;Tempura oil temp.;453.15;Red wine temp.;282.15;Hot 'sake' temp.;318.15
Named for the Swedish scientist A. Celsius in 1742. Defined as one hundredth of temperature difference between the freezing and boiling points of pure water
Named for the French scientist René-Antoine Ferchault de Réaumur (1683-1757). The interval between the freezing and boiling temperatures of water equals to 80 °r instead of 100 °C
